ALLEGATION:
The staff at Bay Pines Center are not allowing the residents to call their workers or
attorneys even though it has been court ordered to do so.
INVESTIGATION:
The Bureau of Juvenile Justice has the following policy:
R2 211 1 of 2 YOUTH USE OF TELEPHONE JRB 2013-001 5-1-2013
RESIDENT PROGRAMS STATE OF MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH &
HUMAN SERVICES
POLICY
It is the policy of the Michigan Department of Human Services Bureau of Juvenile
Justice (BJJ) that youth will have reasonable access to telephones.
PURPOSE
This policy states the minimum requirements for the youth’s use of the telephone.
PROCEDURE
Each facility is required to develop and implement standard operating procedures
(SOPs) relative to the use of telephone by youth. At a minimum, these SOPs must
contain the following requirements:
Access to Telephone and Authorized Charges
Youths in residential care programs are permitted access to telephones.
Youths are permitted to make at least two (2) telephone calls per week to parties
approved by the youth, parents, JJS, CMO worker, or probation officer at
established times.
An approved list of incoming and outgoing telephone calls is readily available to
program staff.
Facilities will allow for reasonable privacy of telephone calls within program
parameters.
Staff will not listen to an outside party’s portion of a telephone conversation without
the outside party’s consent or a court order.
Resident B was interviewed on 06/24/2019 at the facility. She said, “you get two
phone calls per week” “if you call your worker it takes away from a family call”.

Resident D was interviewed on 06/24/2019 at Bay Pines Center. Resident D said,
“you give up a parent phone call to call your worker. She said that May 2019 is the
last month for this policy because of complaints by the residents. Resident D said
the boys’ side did not have to follow the same rule and they could call their workers
without losing a family call.
Resident E was interviewed at the facility on 07/17/2019. She said you had to give
up a family call if you were going to call your attorney. Resident E said that Resident
C brought this up at a court hearing and the judge said that Bay Pines could not take
phone calls away. Resident E said that they are allowed 2 fifteen minutes phone
calls per week.
Resident A was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2019. She said regarding the
telephone policy, “it is changed now, one or two weeks ago, we can call our workers
now without reducing our family calls.”
Resident I, Resident K, Resident L, and Resident M were interviewed at the facility
on 01/29/2020 and reported no problems with being able to call their parents,
workers and lawyers.
Staff 39, Staff 40, Staff 9, Staff 38 and Staff 10 were interviewed at the facility on
01/29/2020. They all said that phone calls were not an issue and the facility had set
telephone times for residents and phone calls to lawyers and workers were arranged
by the group leaders.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4124 Communication
An institution shall have and follow a written policy regarding
communication that ensures that a child is able to communicate
with family and friends in a manner appropriate to the child’s
functioning and consistent with the child’s treatment plan and
security level.
ANALYSIS: Based on the Bureau of Juvenile Justice policy and the
interviews Bay Pines Center is following their required written
policy. The policy indicates youth are required to have at least
two calls a week, which the youth report they were allowed, they
were just divided between workers and family. Therefore, rule
non-compliance is not established.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

ALLEGATION:
A resident had a pencil and threatened to stab the other residents and staff did not
do anything to stop it.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident E was interviewed at the facility on 07/17/2019. Resident E said Former
Resident H threatened Resident B with a pencil and staff did not take the pencil.
Resident E could not say which staff or when this incident took place. Resident E
said that Resident B felt unsafe around Former Resident H. Resident H was
discharged from Bay Pines Center on 07/10/2019. Resident E said that Former
Resident H and Resident B were fighting, and they were both sent to their rooms.
Resident E did not know the dates of this fight or which staff were working.
Staff 2 said that she witnessed the incident with Former Resident H and Resident B
when interviewed at the facility on 07/17/2019. Staff 2 said that Former Resident H
only pretended to stab Resident B with a pencil. Staff 2 said she could not remember
the date or who else was working at the time.
Resident A was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2019. Resident A said that
Former Resident H threatened Resident B with a pencil and “never had the pencil
taken away from her”. Resident A could not remember when this incident took place
or which staff were working.
Resident B was interviewed at the facility on 06/24/2019. Resident B said that
Former Resident H threatened Resident E with a pencil and Staff 6 was working at
the time. Resident B could not remember when this incident occurred.
Staff 6 was interviewed by telephone on 08/15/2019 she said that she did not
remember an incident with a pencil and Former Resident H and Resident B. She
said that Former Resident H was very aggressive and had many incidents. Staff 6
said she did remember slightly an incident with a pencil between Former Resident H
and Resident E. Staff 6 said she would need the date of the incident so she could
look it up in the “log”.
The facility has a video system; however, the incident could not be reviewed due to
not having a specific timeframe to review for.
Resident B was re-interviewed for this special investigation at the facility on
01/28/2020. Resident B first said that Former Resident H never threatened her with
a pencil. She said Former Resident H looked upon her as “a little sister”. Resident B
then said that Former Resident H was “just joking around”. Resident B went on to
say that staff “should have stopped her (Former Resident H)” so that she did not
escalate the joke.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency’s program statement and
to provide for the continual needs, protection, and supervision of
residents.
ANALYSIS: Based on the interviews, rule noncompliance cannot be
established. Rule non-compliance cannot be found because of
the lack of specific information. Resident H did not stab
Resident B with a pencil. The only staff who remember the
incident said it was in a joking manner. The staff had Resident H
under supervisor in a secure unit. The complaint by the other
residents was the Resident H was not put seclusion. There is no
behavior reported that warranted seclusion.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION 1:
Somebody inside of Bay Pines Center wrote an email to the court saying how the
residents were being treated and ever since that they are mistreating them, even
more. They belittle the residents, lie to them, antagonize them, and say "shut your
mouth."
INVESTIGATION:
Residents A, B, C, and D were interviewed at the facility and all said that some staff
were rude to them, but they could not name individual staff or times and places.
Resident B said the residents never lie to staff but staff lie all the time to the
residents. Resident B and Resident D said Teacher 4 said “shut your mouth”. There
were no other examples able to be provided by Resident A, B, C, and D as to how
staff belittle them and antagonize them. Resident F said that sometimes staff
“belittle” the residents, but was unable to explain what this meant.
Former Administrator 3 did an internal investigation of the allegations contained in
this special investigation. She interviewed Residents A, B, E, F, and G regarding
how residents were treated at Bay Pines Center. Former Administrator 3 posed the
following question: Do you have concerns about the way you are treated at Bay
Pines Center? To this question Former Administrator 3 wrote the following
responses:

Resident F responded: Yes. Resident F stated she gets called out by peers; her
issues are thrown up. Resident F stated no one really helps her when she is
down. Resident F expects someone to come talk to her and stated she was
referring to her peers. Resident F stated she thinks staff are scared of youth.
Resident F stated staff do not hold youth accountable and gave the example that
Resident A was not redirected today when she was yelling at Resident F.
Resident F stated she sometimes feels unsafe with her peers because they are
bipolar.
Resident G responded: Sometimes. Resident G stated she is in her head at
times and feels like she does not want to graduate and feels more attention going
to other youth and provided the example of Staff 5 working with Resident A,
Resident E and her on school and not responding to her when she was waiting
patiently.
Resident B responded: Disrespected by staff. Resident B gave the example that
Staff 6 got mad that she was cussing and told her to go to her room.
Resident E responded: Yes. Not treated like a human, disrespected even though
she said she is disrespectful to staff, and Staff 6 criticizes her. Resident E could
not give any specific examples.
Resident A responded: Yes. Disrespect from Staff 6 and gave the example that
Staff 6 told Resident A that what she says does not matter and that Staff 6
laughs when youth are angry and puts youth in their bedrooms. Resident A
stated Staff 6 picks and tells her what to do and that she is not consistent and
gave the example of when a room search was completed she had two glasses
cases in her room and nothing was said about this however on the last room
search it was document that Resident A had two glasses cases. Resident A
gave an example of Staff 6 being disrespectful as Staff 6 at times gives warnings
for swearing and other times will send a youth to their room for a time out for
swearing.
Resident E was interviewed by this licensing consultant on 07/17/2019 she said that
staff lie. They say step into your room for 15 minutes and it turns into an hour and
25-30 minutes.
Staff 2 was interviewed by this licensing consultant on 07/17/2019 and she said she
never heard staff say, “shut your mouth” and she had never said that to residents.
Staff 2 said she never heard about an email to the court.
Resident B was interviewed on 01/28/2020 she said that she had never heard of an
email to the court.
Resident I, Resident K, Resident L, and Resident M were interviewed at the facility
on 01/29/2020 and reported no issues with staff being rude or belittling residents.

Staff 39, Staff 40, Staff 9, Staff 38 and Staff 10 were interviewed at the facility on
01/29/2020. They all said that they had never heard name calling or “belittling” of
residents. Staff 10 said that residents complain when they are held accountable.
Staff 39 said he had not seen staff belittle or be rude to residents.
ALLEGATION 2:
A teacher told a resident that he was going to show up at her house, and she told
him "no" so he got angry at her and his face turned red. The same teacher got
excited when a marker hit his crotch like he was turned on.
INVESTIGATION:
Former Administrator 3 did an internal investigation of the above allegation and
provided the following narrative:
Interviewed Teacher 4 on 7/11/2019 at 12:25pm. Teacher 4 reported that he did
not recall an incident involving a marker being thrown. Teacher 4 did recall a
situation regarding the journal and Resident C asking to take her English journal
home. Teacher 4 told her that it could be mailed or even delivered to her once
she leaves. Teacher 4 stated the girls then began talking about how he would be
hand delivering it. Teacher 4 then stated he told the girls a story about one time
when he kicked 20 kids off the bus because they were being unsafe and that he
transported some of these youth back and forth to school with the parent’s
permission. Teacher 4 stated that the girls took his statement out of context.
Resident D was interviewed at the facility on 06/24/2019. Resident D said Teacher 4
told Resident C regarding a notebook, “I will hand it to you at your house”. Resident
D said that Resident A threw a marker back at Teacher 4 and hit him in the crotch.
Teacher 4 left the facility in July of 2019 and was not available to be interviewed by
this licensing consultant.
Resident C left the facility on 06/27/2019 and was not available to be interviewed
further regarding the above alleged incident.
Resident D said Resident A said, “you are giggling like you like it” referring to the
marker hitting Teacher 4 in the crotch Resident D said Teacher 4 “laughed even
more”.
Resident B was interviewed at the facility on 06/24/2019. Resident B said that
Resident A threw a marker at Teacher 4 and hit him in the crotch. Resident B said, “I
was disgusted”. Teacher 4 left the facility in August 2019 and was not available to
be interviewed for this special investigation.

Resident B was re-interviewed on 01/28/2020. When asked about Teacher 4 and the
marker, she said that Resident C threw a marker at Teacher 4 and hit him in the
private area, and Teacher 4 laughed.
On the days this licensing consultant was at Bay Pines Center Teacher 4 was not
available to be interviewed.
Resident E was interviewed at the facility on 07/17/2019 and said that she was “not
there for the marker” incident.
Resident A was interviewed on 07/23/2019. When Resident A was asked about the
marker incident, she said that she thought Teacher 4 had “boundary issues’ and
went on to say, “I think there is something wrong with him”. Resident A did not say
why she thought something was wrong with Teacher 4.
APPLICABLE RULE
Staff qualifications.
R 400.4112
(1) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Allegation 1:
There is insufficient evidence based on interviews with residents
to establish that staff are mistreating or talking poorly to
residents.
Allegation 2:
The teacher was not available to be interviewed. However,
Former Administrator 3 reported interviewing the teacher about
these allegations and denied saying anything inappropriate and
did not recall the marker being thrown at him. Interviews with
Residents indicate that a marker may have been thrown at the
teacher, but other than the girls’ speculations about how the
teacher felt about this, there is no evidence to support anything
improper occurred.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Residents are only allowed to be in their rooms for up to 72 hours, but they left a
resident, Resident A, in her room for 85 hours.

INVESTIGATION:
Former Administrator 3 did an internal investigation of the above allegation and
provided the following narrative:
Reviewed the girl’s logbook from 6/4/2019 regarding the concern (f) about a
youth being in their room for over 72 hours. The logbook reflects on 6/3/2019 at
7:15pm Resident A cussed saying “fuck” at which time she was asked to circle
up. Resident A began being disrespectful during the circle and was given a 15-
minute chair restriction. Resident A then asked to self-step as Resident A tends
to do this to avoid taking responsibility. Resident A was told no and demanded
for Staff 6 to call the supervisor. Staff 6 told Resident A no at which time
Resident A grabbed for Staff 6’s radio. Resident A was placed in her room for
the night. The next morning at 6:14am Resident A was at her door asking to
come out and was told not at that time and Resident A began swearing.
Resident A then proceeded to cover her window. When shift supervisor went to
give Resident A her due process paperwork indicating that she had a 24 hour
and was given her breakfast at which time, she shoved her breakfast at staff and
began charging staff. Resident A was restrained and due to this and placed on a
72 hour due process. Resident A began working her exit strategy 6/7/19 at
6:17am.
According to MiSACWIS (Michigan Statewide Automated Child Welfare Information
System), Resident A was placed in seclusion on 06/03/2019 at 7:15 p.m. and was
released from seclusion on 06/06/2019 at 8:30 pm. The reason for seclusion was
stated as Assault by Child Without Injury, Misconduct, and Physical Restraint. The
MiSACWIS narrative was as follows:
Staff 7 had Resident A's door open speaking to her. Staff 7 and Staff 8 were
being aware of conversation. Before Resident A’s door was shut Staff 8 tried to
pass youth Resident A her breakfast. Resident A shoved her tray into staff while
charging at staff. Resident A was restrained, and Resident A's room was emptied
as Resident A had covered her window. Resident A was on a DRC (Disciplinary
Room Confinement) at the time of this incident.
Resident A was interviewed on 07/23/2019 she said she was left locked in her room
for 85 hours.
Resident B was interviewed on 07/17/2019 she said Resident A was in her room for
85 hours.
The Bureau of Juvenile Justice policy was reviewed and states that a resident is not
to be confined in their locked bedroom for longer than 72 hours. In the above
incident with Resident A, was confined for a longer period.

Former Administrator 3, in her report regarding these allegations, wrote the+
following:
Upon looking into this allegation, it appears that (Resident A) was placed in her
room on 6/3/19 at 7:15pm for 24 hours on a Due Process. Then on 6/4/19
(Resident A) charged at staff and was given a 72 hour. I am concerned with this
as she was already in her room and the 72 hours was added on to the time and
she began her exit strategy on 6/7/19 at 6:17am. This will be addressed with
supervisors during the August monthly supervisor meeting.
Resident B was re-interviewed on 01/28/2020, she said she never heard of a
problem with toilet paper when Resident A was in her room for 85 hours.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4163 Secure facilities serving juvenile justice youth; seclusion
room
(2) The institution shall establish and follow a written policy,
which, at a minimum, includes all of the following:
(d) A sanction of room confinement shall not exceed 72
hours inclusive of any time spent in seclusion for out-of-
control behavior at the time of the incident itself.
Sanctions of 72 hours shall be reserved for only the most
serious misconduct.
ANALYSIS: In the above incident with Resident A, Former Administrator 3’s
report is that Resident A was confined on 06/03/2019 at 7:15pm.
Staff then added a 72-hour room confinement on 06/04/2019 at
6:14 a.m, while Resident A was already confined to her room.
Resident was released on 06/07/2019 at 6:17 a.m. Therefore,
the 72-hour time limit was exceeded by 11 hours and 2 minutes,
as the rule indicates that the maximum time is 72-hours
inclusive of any time spend in seclusion at the time of the
incident itself.
The report in MiSACWIS states Resident A was placed in
seclusion on 06/03/2019 at 7:15 p.m. and the time out was listed
as 06/06/2019 at 8:30 p.m., for a total of 73 hours and 15
minutes.
Therefore, regardless of how the time is calculated, Resident A
was confined beyond 72-hours.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ALLEGATION:
A resident showed their private parts to Resident A and staff didn't do anything about
it.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident A was interviewed at the facility on 07/23/2019. She said that Resident B
showed her breast and vaginal area to her. Resident A said that all the girls on the
unit and the staff knew about it.
Resident A said that this occurred on the “pod” and Resident B exposed herself to
Resident A as Resident A looked in the window of Resident B’s bedroom door.
Resident B was interviewed at Bay Pines Center on 06/24/2019. She said she
exposed herself to Resident A and the staff “put her blocker up”. A blocker is a cover
to the window on the bedroom door. Resident B went on to say that exposing herself
to peers is one of her problems and she is working on it. Resident B was re-
interviewed on 01/28/2020. She said that Resident A looked into her room when she
was naked. She said she “stopped doing all that”.
Resident B’s case record documents were reviewed on 01/01/2020. According to the
case record Resident B has a long history of trauma and acting out behaviors. It was
reported that she has made over 50 allegations that she was a victim of sexual
abuse. The case plan is to have Resident B participate in Eye Movement
Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR), Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
and Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT). The “blocker” in the window of the
resident’s bedroom door is used when privacy is required, during normal time and
sleeping hours the window is not blocked to provide supervision and safety.
A safety plan was reviewed, dated 05/28/2019 and signed by Resident B. One the
elements was “(Resident B) gave a verbal commitment to not show any of her body
parts including breast and vagina to staff or youth.” The safety plan also specified
that Resident B’s door window blocker was to remain down (so staff could see into
the room) unless Resident B asked permission when she was changing her clothes
or using the bathroom.
Bay Pines Center is a secure treatment center in which the residents are secure in a
locked bedroom during sleeping hours. Resident can also voluntary go to their
rooms. The rooms have a magnetic lock which staff use a card or key fob to open
the rooms. The staff are required to do contact room checks when a resident is in his
or her room. The privacy blocker that covers the window must be down so the staff
can check for the wellbeing of the resident. In the case of Resident B, her blocker
has to be down when she is in her room so the staff can do the required checks. The
safety plan above instructs other residents to stay away from Resident B’s room

window and only allows the window blocker to be up if Resident B is using the
bathroom facilities in her room or changing her clothes.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
(1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
ANALYSIS: Staff developed a staff plan with Resident B requiring her not to
expose herself to other residents and requiring the other
residents to avoid Resident B’s room.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The Bay Pines Center has had multiple investigations, but nothing has been done
and the Director has been made aware of these allegations but will not do anything
about it. Staff are refusing to give incident reports to the residents when something
occurs.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident B, and Resident D were interviewed on 06/24/2019. Resident A, Resident
E, and Resident C were interviewed on 07/17/2019. Resident A was re-interviewed
on 07/23/2019. They all said that they did not receive copies on incident reports.
Former Administrator 3 was interviewed by telephone on 08/16/2019 and she said
that having residents get copies of incident reports is not their policy. She said the
reports are placed in the residents’ case record and shared with the caseworkers
and courts.
Bay Pines Center’s written procedure regarding incident reports was requested of
Former Administrator 3. The policy was sent via email and reviewed by this licensing
consultant. There was nothing in Bay Pines Center’s policy that mentioned or
required the giving of incident reports to residents.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4150 Incident reporting.
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or illness
requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported to the
parent/ legal guardian, responsible referring agency, and the
licensing authority as soon as possible, but not more than 24
hours after the incident.
(2) The death of a resident shall be reported immediately to the
parent/legal guardian or next of kin, law enforcement, the
licensing authority, and the referring agency.
(3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without
legal permission, then the Institution shall immediately report
the information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian
or next of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring
agency.
(4) When a resident’s behavior results in contact with law
enforcement, the incident shall be reported to the
parent/legal guardian, responsible referring agency, and the
licensing authority as soon as possible, but not more than 24
hours after the incident.
ANALYSIS: It is not the policy of Bay Pines Center to give copies of Incident
Reports to residents.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

Staff 6 asked for Resident E's brush due to previously self-harming herself.

APPLICABLE RULE
Resident restraint.
R 400.4159
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the minor
child’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,

standards. When asked about a “boys BBQ” the staff member said that all the
residents get the same food at each meal.
Bay Pines Center is both a detention and a state training school. In this list of
complaints, the female residents said that “special needs” residents were treated
better than the other residents. The residents provide no specifics. The staff

R 400.4109 Program statement.

ANALYSIS: Allegation 1:
There was no indication that staff are leaving employment at the
facility due to the way kids are treated.
Allegation 2:
Based on the lack of specific incidents and the interviews of

ALLEGATION:
Residents mattresses get taken away, and they are made to sleep on the floor.
INVESTIGATION:
Former Administrator 3 in her report for this special investigation stated the
following:
Youth mattresses have been taken out of youth’s rooms when they are being
utilized to cover their windows, block their doors and create safety issues. Youth
who are on suicide watch may also have their mattress removed if it is deemed
to be a safety risk.

Resident B said on 06/24/2019 the mattress is removed if a resident refuses to “self-
step” into their room for disciplinary reasons. This happens when a resident refuses
for more than 15 minutes according to Resident B. Resident B was re-interviewed on
01/28/2020, she said that mattress were taken away for safety. Resident B said that
the mattresses were returned at 8 p.m. 0r 8:30 p.m. depending on the resident’s
bedtime.
Resident D said on 06/24/2019 that when mattresses are removed residents were
not on the floor but on a platform and a hard-plastic surface.
Resident A said on 07/23/2019 that staff quit taking out the mattresses. The
mattress and bedding is removed when a resident is out of control and in danger of
self-harm.
Administrator 3 reported mattress are removed for safety reason that the resident’s
mattress is returned as soon as staff is reasonably sure that the resident is under
control and that self-harm is not an issue.
Staff 39, Staff 40, Staff 9, Staff 38 and Staff 10 were interviewed at the facility on
01/29/2020. They all said that the mattresses are always returned at bedtime.
Residents’ only have their mattress taken if there was a safety issue, but it was
always returned at either 8 p.m. or 8:30 p.m.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4138 Bedding and linen.
Each resident shall be provided with an individual bed with a
clean pillow, mattress and sufficient clean blankets.
ANALYSIS: Based on the interviews and policy of Bay Pines, the removing
of a mattress is only done to provide safety for the residents,
and is returned to them at bedtime; therefore, rule non-
compliance cannot be established.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The staff talk about the residents outside of work by texting over the phone.

INVESTIGATION:
Former Administrator 3 in her report for this special investigation stated the
following:
Upon speaking with the youth, they indicated that two staff talked about how they
were going to handle a situation over the phone/text. It was not stated if names
were used or if it was about the pod in general.
Interview with Staff 6 on 7/11/19 at 10:10pm. Asked Staff 6 if she has ever
informed the girls of her and Staff 9 talking/texting about the youth at BPC. Staff
6 stated that she has talked with Staff 9 via messenger if it has been a rough
night and that this has occurred 10-15 times however that she has never used
specifics or a youth’s name and has never breached confidentiality. Also in the
log book on 6/4/19 it is logged that Staff 6 told the girls that it was a team
decision regarding pod restrictions. Resident C then stated the whole team was
not there and Staff 6 indicated that the team has their ways of communicating
which Staff 6 writes in the log that the team just backs up the team and Resident
C then states that they are talking on Facebook and messenger and that is a
confidentiality issue.
Resident D said “staff talk and text over the phone about residents when they are at
home. Staff call the unit from home to discuss consequences for the group”.
Staff 1 said on 06/24/2019 she was not aware of any staff communicating using their
phones.
Staff 6 was interviewed by telephone on 08/16/2019.She said that staff on the girl’s
pod basically communicate with each other in person. She said occasionally they will
call into to unit from home. Staff 6 said that cell phones are not allowed in the
treatment area of Bay Pines Center. Staff 6 said the main way staff communicate
regarding residents is in person or through the “log book” were notes are placed
regarding residents.
Staff 9 was interviewed by telephone on 01/24/2020. She stated that there is never
any texting or messaging with Messenger about residents. She said that she has
communicated to new staff in a supportive way on those platforms but never violated
resident confidentiality. She said she has worked for Bay Pines for seventeen years
and likes to provide support for the newer staff.
Resident B was re-interviewed on 01/28/2020 and she said that she knew nothing
about staff texting.
Staff 39, Staff 40, Staff 9, Staff 38 and Staff 10 were interviewed at the facility on
01/29/2020. They all said that staff are not to have their phones on the units when

residents are awake. Cell phones are put in a locked cabinet when staff come to
work and cell phones ae not allow on the treatment units.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
(1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
ANALYSIS: There is no evidence that staff are using cell phones at work to
communicate confidential information about residents. The only
use reported is a supervisor to new worker to provide support,
or staff discussing general information about work, not specific
to any one resident. Staff reported that cell phones are put in a
locked cabinet when staff come to work and cell phones are not
allow on the treatment units.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

With an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that no change be
made to the license of this public child caring institution
